reviewText:
as a fan of the movies its hard to get into Back to the future games. over the years various ones have came out and most of them were garbage. Now i wished there was 3 options to choose for a review for games such as neutral. there are sometimes where we feel a game was decent but lacked on certain things. for me this is one of them. I enjoyed the voice acting. The story was not too bad.


I'm one of those people that came off playing Walking Dead, Wolf among us, Game of Thrones before this game. So i was thinking there would be something similar.  But i tried their game Sam and max before this one so then i realized not all of their games would be like that. First thing that annoyed me was the controls and the camera. this was using a 360 controller. Sometimes it wouldn't react or i couldn't figure out what to use my buttons on. So i would have to actually use my mouse. So that defeated the controller purpose. the game being broken into 5 titles is only a small annoyance.


So i only did complete one chapter atm but im mixed at the game. I'm not sure if this will be one i will finish because of the controls and camera annoying me. Now don't get me wrong if you can get it to work then it might not be so bad. i can't recommend this at full price. bundle or major sale maybe.

reviewText:
This was VERY hard for me to say, because there really is a lot to like about this game (I wish Steam would allow us a third option when voting).  The problem is, overall, the pros don't outway the cons.

As far as the GOOD things: the story feels very much like a BTTF movie.  Fans of the movies will no doubt love the fact that some of the original voice actors returned.  The story is good, some of the new characters are interesting, and overall, it's entertaining.

Now, why don't I recommend this game?  If you take off the nostalgic glasses and look at it for what it is, it's not that great.  While I said the storyline was good, it's not GREAT, which is what you would hope for from a game based off the iconic movies (which I myself love).  The plot is very linear (there's not much in the way of choice), and the story doesn't get really interesting until much later in the game.  Also, the setting of a prohibition-era Hill Valley just isn't very captivating.

In addition, the puzzles vary from being either too easy or too vague to get through without hints (the guitar battle is a good example).  Also, and I know this is minor, but the animation is like something out of a kid's cartoon, which contrasts awkwardly with the adult humor and cussing.  There's more I could say, but that would just be rambling.


Overall, if you're a big fan of the movies and can get this game on sale, then YES, buy this game!  But if you're an average Joe looking for a game as good as their later efforts (The Walking Dead; Wolf Among Us), you'll be disappointed.  You'd be better off spending your money on a different title.

reviewText:
Garbage with a side of nostalgia
tl;dr - The only value of this game is the desire for Back to the Future feels. I'd grab it on sale merely for this purpose. If you're looking for a remarkable game and have no designs on the movies, don't waste your time.

The game opens with familiarity. Doc is testing his time machine then something goes awry. Lo and behold the true story begins. Now you're in the mix and you're in point and click mode, which is the only good part about the controls to this game. Once you have to navigate off screen, you're forced to click, hold and drag to move your character. After my play through, I went back and tried asdw and the arrow keys to move and it worked. Something not explained through regular gameplay, but I digress. The puzzles aren't inherently hard. With enough dialogue and random clicking, you can figure out most of them without a hint.

The first episode brings you back to the movies. The second lingers on the same familiarity. By the third episode, I wanted to rush through just to beat the game. The fourth pulls you back in a bit and finally, when you know it's finishing up, the fifth brings you back to feels. Until the end, when it drags feet again, but it's okay because it will wrap up soon, the Delorean will drive into the screen and you will wish you could have it back all over again. The episodes don't link from your gameplay so items you collected do not transfer and neither do your choices. No matter what you name yourself in the first game, your name will be changed in the following.

Speaking of episodes, who's idea was it to make you buy a game then repeatedly buy the same game multiple times. Well, it's not an entirely new concept, DLC has been going on for a few years now to rehash old sh**, but for this type of game? I'm not quite sure how much they forced you into spending in the long run, as I bought the game with all the episodes on sale for $4.99, but come on. The listing price was $19.99 and for the life of me I can't possibly think of how it could have been sold for more than $5.00. I spent about 2 hours per episode, with the exception of episode 3 where I walked away to eat and bullsh** for a while bringing my total to around 6 hours.

Edna and young doc, separately and together, annoyed the ♥♥♥♥ out of me. The dialogue wasn't completely terrible, but I'm not sure as to why there were so many Star Wars references thrown in. There were also quite a few glitches in the episodes which made dialogue and entire scenese skip.

All in all, I'd say for the $5 it's worth the nostalgia, but the game as a whole is doodoo.

Good luck!

reviewText: Yeah, so, my game time isn't accurate. I forgot I had it open! Anyway, I'd say the total game time for one episode was right around 2 hours. This is an older episode game from Telltale and it does show, to a degree. The Telltale engine works well and it has carried them on through recent releases, and it holds up rather well in that respect. In this, you can set your expectation to what you would (in terms of graphics) for a game released around this time - it looks pretty good, but certainly not what we expect in 2014, but still fun to look at! Some things haven't held up this well, at all.\n\nThe good and the bad are in equal supply with this, I think it looks adorable and the characters and voice acting are fantastic. Telltale really has a talent for making things like Back To The Future, The Wolf Among Us, The Walking Dead, etc., really come to life and be fun again. reviewText:
This is a point and click game based on the Back to the Future movie franchise. It has everything going for it, the music straight from the movie, the nostalgia, the amazing voice cast and the immersion that lets you explore a lot from the movie. This is some good interactive fiction and a point and click was the way to go to tell a story. The only real problem here is the genre just isn't all that fun.

The story has you going back in time as Marty McFly from the movies to find Doc Brown and really puts a focus on Doc's youth instead of the movies that put the focus on Marty's family and him saving it. Most of the characters are here from the movie, Marty, his dad George McFly, Doc Brown, Einstein the dog and of course Biff Tannen. It introduces more characters, but they're not the stars. Biff's voice actor could have sounded more like Biff, but Marty's voice actor is fantastic and Doc is played by Christopher Lloyd as always.

Since this is a modern point and click game that lets you walk around an area instead of being confined to one screen like the older version of the genre. You'll be able to collect items and use them. That's one of the problems, the tedium of using the items. Going into the item menu, selecting the item, using the item and if you fail then you need to do it all over again. Over and over. , You'll be figuring out what dialog choice you need to make, which character to distract so you can do something with them gone. At least with this and other modern point and click games they accentuate what to click on.

I can't say the game is fun and to be honest it feels like a chore to sit through the story. There aren't any crazy moments like in the movie so much as dialog and wandering around. I can't imagine non gamers that are fans of the movie franchise sitting down to enjoy this game and play it all the way through. I can't imagine gamers saying wow that was fun, unless this was the 90s when point and click games were more accepted, before technology left them behind.

For the most part, the game is a series of cut scenes to say even the simplest of things. Potentially over and over again. There is some interactivity when you chat with someone, but it feels more like how much flavor dialog do you want to hear? There is always a logical choice with dialog and there are no wrong choices, so much as do you want to listen to all 3 - 5 responses or pick the most logical one to get it over with and progress? There are no real consequences like in Walking Dead where it can change characters and or events. You'll always get through the game. There is no death, there is no failure, there is just pressing on until you figure out what to do next.

I've always been a big fan of the Back to the Future movie franchise, and I really enjoyed my first play through of Walking Dead, which is also from Telltale Games, but this game is a chore. The story and the nostalgia just aren't enough to make me want to see what happens next.

reviewText:
Im a huge fan of telltale, and my friend is a huge fan of Back To the Future. How could a Telltale game about Back to the Future go wrong? Easy, by not being a Telltale game to begin with. I dont know if they outsourced this game, or if the art department took the day off and left it to the interns but wow... this game is ugly. The lip syching is awful, and the characters faces lack the complexity to properly emote.

But how does it play? Again... nothing like a Telltale game. Instead of a story on rails where you get to occassionally switch tracks to fit your preference, Back to the Future is a point and click puzzle game... do you know how unexciting it is to play a puzzle game coop? The story moves like molassus because your constantly moving back and forth, reading the same dialogue, trying to figure out what item you need, or what line of dialogue will reveal the clue. The pacing was so bad me and my friend quit before chapter 2 was even finished because it was soooo slow.

In short, this is a slow, point and click puzzle game, NOT a typical Telltale game... because those are entertaining, this game is not.

reviewText:
Okay, I've seen Back To The Future hundreds of times (I'm not exaggerating, I wish I was). I was thrilled when this game came out and I finally was able to buy it. When we arrive at this point I have to admit that I like almost anything BTTF related, even the animated series. But this game... This game makes me angry. I've played two other games by telltale and I quite love it, but this game is outrageous.

There is not difficulty on this, in every location you have normally three/four things to interact with, you don't carry many objects with you (you can count it with your hand's fingers) and any conversation eventually leads with what the developers want to. You can't get lost somewhere because there's so little things to do and so little things to talk about that there is literally NO WAY to miss something. What I hated the most were the conversations where you had three options but the three of them where basically the same. What's the point then?

So the interesting thing about this game is not playing it but watching it and see how the story goes and... Nope. The story is just not worth it, really simple and plain, full of plot holes and the graphics don't help. They're good enough to be bad and get you out of focus.

The gameplay is quite tedious, if you walk from one point to another in some chapters you will cross with somebody and you'll have to watch that terrible animation with that same face with the nodding that EVERY CHARACTER will do. The movement is not the best thing in the world to be honest.

Basically this game consists in clicking two things to see the next animation. Kind of LA Noire but with worse graphics and even worse gameplay.

The only good thing I have to say about this is that this game came out 5 years ago. They released after that Jurassic Park and The Walking Dead and they clearly improved so hey, let's just consider it just a big mistake (praised by the critics and the gamers, I STILL DON'T KNOW WHY).

My veredict: Sadly disappointing.

reviewText:
LOL. Please no. I knew this game wasn't going to be very good (the price fell too quickly), but wow. This game feels so generic. It has a whipser of nostalgia that is strong in the familiar opening scene, but that soons gives way to uninspiring point-and-click blandness. It lacks the polish or atmosphere of TellTale's effort with The Walking Dead.

The Walking Dead plays out like a well-done effort by a developer's first team based on a popular franchise in a very popular genre while BttF:TG plays like a rushed effort by a developer's second or third team based upon a franchise that was huge 30 years ago in a genre that has outgrown its boyish charm.

tl;dr My Steam library is bloated and neglected but I like the vast majority of what is there. I keep my games in several categories. One category is for games I would pay Valve to remove from my library. Welcome Back to the Future: The Game, inductee #7.

reviewText:
Don't get me wrong, I'm a huge fan of the Back to the Future franchise. I remember watching them in theatres when they first came out.

I find this game dull and boring. You have to go all over the place finding things to progress the story.

Currently I'm stuck on getting the supoena to Artie McFly, and getting some alcohol from the Soup Kitchen, and no matter what I do, nothing works.

This game is way too tedious, and not true to the franchise at all. And the fact that you can't skip dialogue really lowers my opinion. Definitely not worth the $25 they're asking. Maybe $3-$5 but not $25. This game may just end up taking up space in my library. Such a shame too. I was really looking forward to it.

Haven't tried all Tell-Tale games, but the ones I have, have disappointed me. Imo, they're not a very good company.

Maybe I'll come back to this someday when I feel like being bored out of my mind.

Edit: Had to look it up. Finally beat Episode One. Still not that great.

reviewText:
Back to the Future: The Game consists of five episodes which are a sequel to the movie trilogy.
Doc Brown the inventor of the time machine has gone back to the '30s and he will die via mob justice. Now its up to you to change his fate, but as we learned from the movies, screwing with the past mucks up the future. The goal is to make sure the Hill Valley of 1986 is just how Marty left it.
Telltale fail miserably at making their own circa 1931 Hill Valley anything more than a studio lot full of comedy gangsters.
The gameplay is traditional adventure stuff. You walk around as Marty, talk to citizens and use items to solve puzzles. Unfortunately the puzzles are very easy, uninspired and boring.
The characters are just as bland, also most of the characters are cardboard nobodies. At least, in some cases, the acting is good. On the most basic level, the actors sound like the original characters.
The graphics do not render smoothly and the worst part is that these tech problems distract from the cinematic gameplay.
The sounds of the game are pretty decent. Music is mostly in the background and not too distracting and actual sound effects also take a backseat in favour of the voice acting. The voice acting is definitely the best part in the game.
If you are a big fan of the movies, then you could think about getting Back to the Fute: The Game. However, if the franchise does not really appeal to you, then this game may not be in your interest because the game practically relies on the player knowing the characters and the setting.

Sound 7/10
Graphics 6/10
Gameplay 3/10
Atmosphere 3/10

If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:
http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guides
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curation

reviewText:
Its a point and click adventure game, but the puzzles only come in two flavours, ridiculously easy (Put the key in the lock) to just bizarrely obscure (working out how to get a barrel of booze from one end of the room to the other without interacting with it) so while about 40% of the game can be solved in seconds the other 20% of the game is just half an hour of watching the same cut scenes over and over again till it triggers the next section of game play...the remaining 40%? walking...just slowly or moderately walking back and forth with little to no extras to carry the game along. the Easter eggs are forced and very literal (Any excuse to force the names of the directors of the film can and will be used)

The game glitches. Alot...sound randomly drops out or amplifies sometimes the cut scenes will glitch through buildings leaving you watching a black screen while they just talk very very slowly...on at least 3 occassions the game completely bricked and wouldnt let me quit so I had to force my computer off and back on again.

the first part came out in 2009 with the rest coming out in 2010...and the graphics...are not great. I wasnt expecting cinematic graphics for a 5-6 year old game...but the graphics are on a par if not marginally better than Late PS2/Very very early PS3 graphics...they all have flappy mouths as well rather than synching the dialogue so sometimes cut scenes just end with a load of flappy heads...I only point out the graphics because the likes of Fallout 3 came out between 2007-2011 and are utterly astounding in terms of quality against this...

The only good things I can say about it is the plot itself isnt terrible. Its got quite a back to the future  feel" but it does come across as boarder fanfic at times (Making up "mary sue" characters and making the heros almost untouchable in terms of having any bad attributes) and that Martys soundalike is really quite good...Doc sounds good...everyone else sounds iffy...

I Payed a £5 for all 5 parts of the game during the summer sale and for a pound a part I'd say it was alright...but avoid paying full price at all costs...Its really not worth it. 4/10"

reviewText:
This is my first Telltale game I have played. I just bought the whole collection. Now let me start off with this: I have never been an adventure game fan. This is why I have stayed away from Telltale games. However, hearing just wonderful, awesome, best game ever reviews I finally let my guard down and purchaseed THEM ALL! Here is my verdict so far.

TL;DR - Adventure game still aren't for me.

Wow, that was a really easy, yet expensive lesson, for me to learn. In a FPS if I shoot someone, they die. If I shoot their arm, they die. If I shoot their face, they die. If I shoot their leg... you get the picture right? Of course you do, you've played FPS b4. Adventure games suffer from constantly having to do exactly what someone decided was the right thing always and conforming your mind to be set completely in track with that person's idea of mindset.

Basically, in adventure games, if I shoot your leg first, but the programer thought I would aim for the arm, they do not die. If I shoot the arm, but there was a hint to shoot the face, then leg, then face, then arm, they do not die. You see why I do not like adventure games? I can't just play them. I have to spend hours figuring out every nuance that some other geek decided was the right way.

BttF is no different. 1.5 hours in and I'm just clicking on every highlighted item, in a static world, wondering what logic the programer decided would work to make a damn barrel of alchohol fall from a shelf. AND THAT is exactly why I wish I had never bought any Telltale game. Definately not ALL OF THEM!

So much buyer's remorse! What have I done?!

reviewText:
After purchasing the complete collection of Same and Max games on Steam, I had high hopes for Back to the Future: The Game. I love Telltale, I love point-and-click adventures, I LOVE Back to the Future. What could go wrong?

Answer: A lot, apparently.

As later chapters were released, the somewhat thin layer of polish that came from the first few chapters very quickly peeled away. Events happened in the wrong order, characters would suddenly pop into scenes they weren't in before. Voice acting would randomly cut out in the middle of a line. The crowning achievement was during a car chase scene, when you could clearly see some sort of editor handle bouncing around behind the vehicle.

The game ends with the tease of a sequel, and I honestly kind of hope that it doesn't get one.

reviewText:
As much as I like the Back to the Future franchise, I can't really recommend this game. Although you can see that Telltale Games put a lot of effort into this project (voices, music, design...), it certainly does not compare to their newer games. There were some episodes where I really had to force myself not to quit because the story was pretty mediocre and the tasks were boring. Episode 3 (Citizen Brown) was probably the best episode of this series.

The biggest issue I have with this game are the bugs, particularly in episode 5. Pretty much at the beginning, in the Glass House, I managed to encouter two game-breaking bugs, which meant I had to do everything all over - twice. That sucked... Plus, the German language version has some serious dubbing problems, i.e. sentences get cut off suddenly, and some sentences haven't been translated at all. Is this a big deal? Yes, if you pay 23 bucks, it certainly is.

Fans of the franchise, however, might want to take a look at this game, if it's on sale.

reviewText: A nice addon to the movies. I recommend this if you're a big fan of the BTTF franchise.
Great story, and funny game.

Great Scott! This game is amazing: great story, true to movies, amazing art direction, it has well written characters, a surpisingly intriguing antagonist and amazing voice-work. The story continues right where Back To The Future part 3 ends, with new adventures and new time periods that neatly fold into a great over-arching story. This review concerns the whole series of Back to the Future.

TL,DR; I had a blast with the series and recommend it, more easily so if you liked the movies.

+ Telltale game engine
+ Back to the Future theme
+ Voice actor A.J. Locascio very closely resembles Fox's voice from the movies
+ Overall good voice acting
+ Believable characters
+ Hours of nostalgia

0 Puzzles of medium challenge

- (the old) Too short, about 2 hours for each of the 5 episodes

First off, the game uses the Telltale[en.wikipedia.org] tool known from adventures like the three new Sam & Max serieses, The Walking Dead, the current Tales from the Borderlands and a number of lesser known games, e.g. Puzzle Agent.
Except for maybe the awful Bone series the tool generally provides easily navigable good-looking scenery. It manages too closely resemble the respective flair and art style of the basic IPs.

Same with this adventure, I was seamlessly brought back to the 1985 setting, then gleefully thrown about. The voice acting did it's part with A.J. Locascio closely imitating Micheal J. Fox's pitch and tremble from the movies.
Characters are believably written and we get to learn more about the McFlys, Browns and Tannens.

The puzzles are not too hard and most of the time logical and with clear intent. This though adds to the episodes being somewhat short. I think I spent around 2 hours per episode making the series roughly a 10 hour experience - an experience of awesome.

Thank you, Telltale, for once more providing a high-class adventure and letting me dive back into the atmosphere of Back to the Future including feelings of hope for and fear of the technology of the future.

Also, the future is now! 2015 is only days away. I hear self-tightening shoes have been done and the hoverboard works if only just. Now, where is the self-drying jacket and the convincing shark hologram?

Five episodes of Back to the Future adventure and reminiscence. Recommended.

If you liked the original Back to the Future movie trilogy, this game is a very worthy successor to that. It's basically Back to the Future part IV, except it's a point 'n' click this time, so you get to solve puzzles. And if that ain't something you like and you just want to get this for the story, well don't worry because there's a hint system in the game that is able to pretty much tell you the solution to everything in case you ever get stuck. The writing's great, has some funny moments, although some of it's attempts to reference the movies are kinda cringe worthy. Oh, and did i mention Christopher Lloyd returns to voice act Emmett Brown in this too? That's pretty sweet too.\n\nI wouldn't recommend this to someone who never watched the movies before. You should though. You really should. And then get this game, because it's entertaining too.
Its damn good!
If you're a BTTF fan... you have to play this. It's basically the 4th movie and it's a lot better than Indiana Jones 4 - even if you can caught up on some of the problem solving.

This review concerns the whole series of Back to the Future.

TL,DR; I had a blast with the series and recommend it, more easily so if you liked the movies.

+ Telltale game engine
+ Back to the Future theme
+ Voice actor A.J. Locascio very closely resembles Fox's voice from the movies
+ Overall good voice acting
+ Believable characters
+ Hours of nostalgia

0 Puzzles of medium challenge

- (the old) Too short, about 2 hours for each of the 5 episodes

First off, the game uses the Telltale[en.wikipedia.org] tool known from adventures like the three new Sam & Max serieses, The Walking Dead, the current Tales from the Borderlands and a number of lesser known games, e.g. Puzzle Agent.
Except for maybe the awful Bone series the tool generally provides easily navigable good-looking scenery. It manages too closely resemble the respective flair and art style of the basic IPs.

Same with this adventure, I was seamlessly brought back to the 1985 setting, then gleefully thrown about. The voice acting did it's part with A.J. Locascio closely imitating Micheal J. Fox's pitch and tremble from the movies.
Characters are believably written and we get to learn more about the McFlys, Browns and Tannens.

The puzzles are not too hard and most of the time logical and with clear intent. This though adds to the episodes being somewhat short. I think I spent around 2 hours per episode making the series roughly a 10 hour experience - an experience of awesome.

Thank you, Telltale, for once more providing a high-class adventure and letting me dive back into the atmosphere of Back to the Future including feelings of hope for and fear of the technology of the future.

Also, the future is now! 2015 is only days away. I hear self-tightening shoes have been done and the hoverboard works if only just. Now, where is the self-drying jacket and the convincing shark hologram?

Five episodes of Back to the Future adventure and reminiscence. Recommended.

voteText: it really does come off in the spirit of the films. (If perhaps on the fan service side of things.)\n\nThe game plays out like most point-and-click adventure games. You move Marty around the environment and interact with specific elements or characters to move the story along. The philosophy for the game seems to be that the story is important above everything. In this regard
helpfulPercent: the puzzles are never overly difficult or distracting from the story. The player is never penalised for their actions which means you are free to go through all the character responses which are often amusing. To this end
votesHelpful: Back to the Future: The Game ends up being a bit more interactive fiction than a game as such. And that's not necessarily a bad thing. The story and acting are engaging and you find that you want to move along as well.\n\nPlaying the game isn't very different to many adventure games. I've always found the genre a bit clunky to move around in and while the developers at Telltale Games add a bit of polish to make the controls a bit forgiving

reviewText: If you are a fan of the BTTF trilogy then you are doing yourself a disservice by not buying this game. It is obviously created with a lot of love and zeal for the series and all of the episodes were thoroughly enjoyable to the point where I did not want them to end. Took 2 hours to complete each episode so you can think of them as 5 brand new plots to add to the original three and they interweave fantastically as well as exploring some interesting new concepts for Marty and Doc to explore, Overall I would give the series as a whole a solid 9.5/10 for a fan of BTTF as it really captures the spirit of the films and has a wonderful art style whilst remaining really undemanding on the hardware seeing as how my laptop could run it at 4k with no dips from 60fps.

The graphics are fun and the motion capture is so well done that it really catches all the details you know from the original characters. The voice acting is simply awsome (sogar auf Deutsch wurden die Originalstimmen benutzt!) and during the cut scenes I sometimes forgot for a few moments that this is just a game and not an animated movie.

If you don't know the movies, sometimes it is probably difficult to keep up, but still a fun game!

The puzzles are well balanced and usually work without using the hint system. I would call this intermediate complexity.

Recommendation? YES YES YES!!!

I'm Dayvis2, and this is my review for Telltale's Back to the Future: The Game!

PLOT:

Some may think that this game is just a play through of the three films, but it is actually a completely new story written by Bob Gale. The game is split into 5 episodes - It's About Time, Get Tannen, Citizen Brown, Double Visions and OUTATIME, and they are all about two hours long, assuring about 10 hours of gameplay. The story is based around 1931 Hill Valley, where gangsters rule the streets and a 17 year old Emmet Brown is creating his first scientific experiments. The game parodies the  history repeats itself " theme in the trilogy
recommended:
Marty almost being hit by a moving object and horrible nightmares followed by a sudden realisation. A true tribute to the films.

GAMEPLAY

The game follows the point and click genre
hoursPlayed: as many other Telltale games do. Unfortunately
helpfulPercent: the game does not feature Quick Time Events or the fact that choices affect the story. Quite a few fun puzzles
votesHelpful:
so you'll need to be ready for some brain twisters!

GRAPHICS

Pretty good graphics. Less comic book style ( as The Walking Dead and The Wolf Among Us have) and more realistic looking.

SUMMARY

A good product
votesTotal: but you can get it for a fiver on some sales
votesFunny: such as the BTTF day one I bought this on.\n\n"

reviewText:
I really love the Back to the future movies but this game is another story.
You can’t compare this game to later Telltale releases.

My first impression of this game?  Wow, this looks old!
After playing through the whole game I must say it really feels and play like a 10 year old game.
Overall the game is OK but it feels very old and slow.
There are plenty of movie references and it definitely got the Back to the Future atmosphere.

The voice acting is fine but the graphics are crude and flat. The environment lacks of life and movement.
The character control is clunky and together with odd camera angles it makes the game a bit annoying after a while.
It’s not a difficult game, the puzzles are fairly easy and quick to solve.
If you get stuck there’s a hint system to tell you what to do or point you in the right direction.

The premise which I recommend it on.
At 5-7€ it might be worth a play through if you’re a Back to the Future fan.
At 22,99€ - No way!  (Price at the time of the review)

A cinematic experience with a good plot set during proibitionism and in several alternate reality present.

reviewText: If you've played the first episode (available for free through Telltale Games) as a demo, don't base the rest of the series on it. This may be the best casual point and click game I have played thus far. The story could not have done a better job of sticking to the Back to the Future setting and mainting the style that fans love so very much. The episodes are absolutely wonderfully thought out and they each progressively blend ino eachother in a way that feels rewarding for completing one without making an addition of another feel forced. I haven't even touched upon the best part:
THE MOTHER. ♥♥♥♥ING. VOICE ACTING.
A.J LoCascio as Marty is so godly. He can not be commended enough for his performance.
Christopher Lloyd himself as Doc. ENOUGH SAID.
To top things off, if you weren't already drooling from amazement,
M. J. Fox cameos in the game and without spoiling anything, it's awesome.

Needless to say, if you are looking to get into point and clicks, you like them already, you like Back to the Future, or all of the above, buy this. Now.

I can't complain considering I'm a BTTF junkie, but I'll have to say I expected alot more. This is really more one of those Click-and-see-if-you're-right games, like the Freedi Fish games I played as a small child. The storyline can be considered canon considering Bob Gale is on the storyboard, but it doesn't stand up to the story the movies had. There is literally almost no action in the game. This might not be so hard to understand, but I've never played a TellTale game before and this might be the norm for their games, but it won't appeal to hardcore gamers, mostly casual,\n\nOverall, an OK game but only reccomended for fans of TellTale and/or Back to the Future. Also, watching the movies is pretty much a necessity.

Awesome pointanclick, I really hope they make a sequel someday.

Definitely an enjoyable game for fans of the original Back to the Future film series or for fans of graphic adventure games such as the venerable Monkey Island Series.

This game has 5 episodes with each one lasting around 3 hours and ending with a cliffhanger. Puzzle difficulty was about right, without making you feel too frustrated. There is also a good ingame hint system so you'll never truly be stuck.

It has an interesting storyline, and almost feels like it could be made into a fourth film in the franchise. Music is very faithful to the series, and the voice acting is very good. The guy who voice-acted as Marty does a very good impression. The original stars Michael J Fox and Christopher Lloyd even lends their voices giving it a very authentic feel.

I personally felt that the story was too short as it ended too soon. There is also no replayability value once the game is completed.

Overall Rating: 7.5 / 10
Well worth to buy for gamers of all ages. A very fun and nostalgic trip.

It isn't as polished as The Walking Dead and is far more linear.  With that being said, it was fun and I most definitely recommend this game.  Christopher Lloyd and A.J. Locascio make the game an absolute blast!  There might be a few things that stump you but there is a hint system that can be put to use to keep the pacing at a steady speed.  It might be obvious but you should defintely only play this game after watching the movies, because I think you would appreciate it more.

Before Telltale games really 'got Adventure Games right for the modern age' with The Walking Dead and The Wolf Among Us there was this.

A funny, easy collection of warped-logic puzzles along with a new setting, plenty of voice talent from Christopher Lloyd, cameo from Michael J Fox, and the writing talent of Bob Gale it's an ideal extension of the original film trilogy that deserves more promotion than it got.

Although it may have worked better to be dragged along for the ride as a standalone animated film this title is entertaining enough to be worth the couple of dollars asked for it - even if the linear chapters don't leave you on the edge of your seat.

Is it well packaged? Not exactly. Is it perfect? I wouldn't say that. Is it recommended? Absolutely.

I don't even like point and click games in the slightest, but I love Back to the Future and I love TellTale. I came for the story and could not have been happier. I was skeptical about their Walking Dead games, and I was skeptical about this as well due to the fact that I love the source material, but wow I'm SO glad I did. Buy this game, trust me if you love a good story and also happen to love BTTF, then you will not regret this purchase. I know I didn't.

It's actually pretty good. (8/10)

Story: Without running into spoiler land I will give you a brief idea of how this story goes. It takes place seven months after the end of the trilogy. This plays into what happens with life after the last movie. Marty is home and Doc is still in the past. Marty, sad at the loss of his friend to time is suddenly interuppted when the DeLorean suddenly appears and Marty is thrust into another adventure.

Appearance: As with many Telltale games this has a cartoon like design. The design is initially off putting with how the movies appear but in no time the art style grows on you. The atmosphere is perfect and captures not only the feel but the over themes of the BTTF movies. This is a perfect continuation.

Gameplay: This is a standard point and click adventure. It has a pretty standard 90's P&C feel to it to a fault. It has many of the issues that plagued those games. Issues getting characters to move properly or collision detection. Over all the game feels well done and is really a joy to play.

Achievements: The only achievement this game came with is having a wonderful time playing the game. The story is reward enough for that.

Bottom Line: This game is such a great deal of fun I regret not playing it sooner. Not only is it the perfect game for a BTTF fan but its a great point and click adventure. Each episode will run you about 2 hours of gameplay for a total 10 hours of gameplay. I picked this up when it was on sale and I would even go so far as to recommend that its even worth the full price. Pick this up at your next chance and give it a go.

So I did the reverse of many people who played the game. I watched the BTTF movies after I played the game. Well I did at some point watch the first movie, but that was forever ago.
I must admit that I understand why so many loves the game with so many familiar elements.

So 10/21/2015 was just here a few days ago, and I had to dive into this game again, just cause f***ing BTTF is amazing. As for the actually games, it's a price that is worth for all 5 episodes! The story is very original, creative, and ties in well with the movie franchise for where it left off on Part III!

Using Telltale Games' gaming engine to incorpurate a very beautiful and emersive world (along with the choice making we all know and love from their games), it brings in for a very amazing and delightful gaming experience!

If your looking into experiencing a story that will tie in into being a legitimate plot or a 4th film (even if it will never come out), this is the closest you can get for Part IV, maybe even better than how the original 3 movies were plotted out!

Just play it!

All right. Let's see, ten minutes ought to do it. Time circuits on, Flux Capacitor... fluxing, engine running, all right!

[the car dies]

...UUuhhhgg This is Heavy!
This game money well spent.

The only problem I have with this is I had to wait almost three decades to play the game based on a very enjoyable movie from my adolescence.  I can't imagine a person would buy only one episode of the five, but it is certainly recommended to buy and play them all.  Each takes maybe 3 hours and hints are provided so that it is almost unnecessary to consult a walkthru, which I liked, and each was short enough to complete in an evening.  A very worthy companion to the movies, and one of the more enjoyable adventure games I have played.  Highly recommended.

It's nice to see a well-crafted point-and-click adventure game of the old-school released every once in a while.  BTTF is one such, bringing together the ridiculous humour of the Telltale gang, a great soundtrack based on the original movies' songs, and fantastic voice acting (though it helps when you get Christoper Lloyd to play Doc again!).  Though while it's entirely worth the $25 price tag ($5 per episode), it's one that I would put on the back burner until there's a good sale on it (that's what I did and usually do anyway).

Unlike other titles from Telltale, your choices don't have any impact in the future (lolz), this game's story is as linear as an arrow.\nHowever the quality of the story itself more then makes up for this flaw.\nIt is pure back to the future greatness <3

Back to the Future: The Game is an add-on to the movie series and made by Telltale who make good games.  Is this game good?  MMM.... a little.  It's funny, sweet, and worth a look.  Even if you don't buy it, if you're a fan of the BttF series, you should at least watch someone play the game.  Each episode's about two and a half hours if you don't get stuck for whatever reason.  You really shouldn't get stuck either if you're an adventure game veteran, the puzzles aren't as obscure as some games' are.

Also you can pick a pop-culture name a la Clint Eastwood in the first game and have it mentioned a lot over the series.  I picked Harry Callahan, no idea who that is either.

Wait for a sale, or watch it on Youtube.  25$ is pretty cheap but...

reviewText: If you are a Back To The Future fan like me then you should buy this game.\n\nThis has a great story, good gameplay. I see this game as the 4th movie.

I love Back to the Future. I long for the days when mvies were this good. The game, while not nearly as good as the film series, does offer enough nostalgia for me to give it a thumbs up. The game is SERIOUSLY helped by Christopher Lloyd's voice. and the actor who played Marty did a surprisingly good job of immitating Michael J Fox's performance. The story is engrossing and fun, and I had a good time with it but it's not perfect. The first episode in particular takes a while to get the ball rolling. and the movement controlls for Marty are somewhat buggy at times. 6.5/10

The good: Great if you're a fan of the original BTTF movie Trilogy, and a helluva lot better than those ♥♥♥♥♥♥ LJN-made NES games. Characters stay faithful to themselves, and EPIC PLOT TWISTS. Also, made by telltale games, the same people who made great point and click adventure games like Sam & Max season 1-3, Strong Bad's Cool Game For Attractive People, and, of course, Poker Night At the Inventory.

The bad: Repetitive voice acting, what you're supossed to do can get confusing from time to time, and not a whole lot of freedom to explore. But don't let any of this get in the way as you put yourself in the shoes of the time traveller Marty McFly.

Overall: I recommend, especially for those who were actually alive in the 80's and saw all 3 movies back when they were released in theatres (unlike me)

voteText: it really does come off in the spirit of the films. (If perhaps on the fan service side of things.)\n\nThe game plays out like most point-and-click adventure games. You move Marty around the environment and interact with specific elements or characters to move the story along. The philosophy for the game seems to be that the story is important above everything. In this regard
helpfulPercent: the puzzles are never overly difficult or distracting from the story. The player is never penalised for their actions which means you are free to go through all the character responses which are often amusing. To this end
votesHelpful: Back to the Future: The Game ends up being a bit more interactive fiction than a game as such. And that's not necessarily a bad thing. The story and acting are engaging and you find that you want to move along as well.\n\nPlaying the game isn't very different to many adventure games. I've always found the genre a bit clunky to move around in and while the developers at Telltale Games add a bit of polish to make the controls a bit forgiving
votesTotal: I find it's really an endemic fault of the genre. I was extremely pleased to find that there was gamepad support for the game and I could take advantage of Big Picture Mode. The gamepad is usable
votesFunny: and I used it for about half of the game

but it is also quite clunky to use.

Otherwise Back to the Future: The Game

reviewText: TellTale has never let me down.  I think the story was a little slow to start, but I'm up to my neck in nostalgia right now. Cannot wait to play #3-5!!! For $10 this is a MUST BUY for adventure gamers.
Good adventure game from TellTale, i recommend this, especially if you liked the movies!

The story for this is really good and I'm going to say that the story in this is better than the Back to the Future movies. Gameplay is good. Puzzles, puzzles, puzzles. And the places you go in this game (even if it is Hill Valley) are very interesting.\n\n5 Episodes all up and so worth your time!

This may be the best casual point and click game I have played thus far. The story could not have done a better job of sticking to the Back to the Future setting and mainting the style that fans love so very much. The episodes are absolutely wonderfully thought out and they each progressively blend ino eachother in a way that feels rewarding for completing one without making an addition of another feel forced. I haven't even touched upon the best part:
THE MOTHER. ♥♥♥♥ING. VOICE ACTING.
A.J LoCascio as Marty is so godly. He can not be commended enough for his performance.
Christopher Lloyd himself as Doc. ENOUGH SAID.
To top things off, if you weren't already drooling from amazement,
M. J. Fox cameos in the game and without spoiling anything, it's awesome.

Needless to say, if you are looking to get into point and clicks, you like them already, you like Back to the Future, or all of the above, buy this. Now.

I can't complain considering I'm a BTTF junkie, but I'll have to say I expected alot more. This is really more one of those Click-and-see-if-you're-right games, like the Freedi Fish games I played as a small child. The storyline can be considered canon considering Bob Gale is on the storyboard, but it doesn't stand up to the story the movies had. There is literally almost no action in the game. This might not be so hard to understand, but I've never played a TellTale game before and this might be the norm for their games, but it won't appeal to hardcore gamers, mostly casual,\n\nOverall, an OK game but only reccomended for fans of TellTale and/or Back to the Future. Also, watching the movies is pretty much a necessity.

If you are a fan of the BTTF movie trilogy, you'll definitely love these games. Don't expect to have usual game play like shooting things and jumping out of windows, this is a story based game, as is the usual with Telltale games, and a rather good one at that. Although it has some plot holes and paradoxical outcomes, it stays true to the original series which also had it's problems (but hey, it was the 80's, okay?) and continues where the third movie left off. I loved this game and played through all five episodes. Worth the price.
An underrated adventure game.

Very few movie liscense games are good. Even fewer are good after it's been years since the release of the movie. This Game is one of the few good ones. By no means is this the best movie liscensed game but in my honest opinion it still has the ability to stand on it's own. Back to the Future is set after the events of the last film in the franchise and as such there are plenty of references to the original movies. The writing still has charm, yet at certain points the game has a different feel to the story of the films, even if it is the same story line. The sound is somewhat subpar in certain places during the game, but at the very least the original soundtrack returns. At times thought, I felt as though I was playing a game for the 6th generation consoles (wii, ps2, xbox). Indeed, the graphics don't have the best polish however if you don't mind the cartoony stylization of the game it shouldn't bother anyone. The gameplay is your average point and click adventure which works in the games favor because making a fps or third person shooter out of this style of game would have been horendous Overall, as a story that expands the lore of the movies this game is pretty great, but stand alone it just okay. I'd suggest that mainly fans of the franchise play this game.

Ok So if you love Back to the Future from the 80's then you have to play this! It's pretty light on the actual gameplay but it's storytelling is excellent. Whilst I was playing it it felt like I was playing and watching Back to the Future part IV!

I decided to go and play this after playing some of Telltales newer games (Walking Dead, Wolf Among Us, Game of Thrones and Tales from the Borderlands). I found the animation to have resemblences and similarities in cartoonish/comic book style to some of the later games. The dialog is a bit more basic than Walking Dead etc, in regards to the responsive and consequences in the situation. The story was flawed in some ways and a little ridiculous in others. It was however enjoyable. The characters had good arcs and grew on you. The light-hearted atmosphere added to the enjoyment and setting the game gave you. The gameplay was sometime a little repetitive but the game/episodes were the right length that it didn't really matter. I would recommend to anyone who enjoys Telltale adventure games, Point and click games, Back to the Future, sci-fi and story based games. 6.5/10

Back to the Future: The Game is pretty much what you'd expect if you're familar with Telltale's more well known games like The Walking Dead or Wolf Among Us.  It's a little older than the other two and it shows in some places, but still holds up overall.  This game isn't always as straight forward as other Telltale games, so you'll probably be making use the game's helpful Hint button to guide you along.  The story is good and take the franchise to some interesting places that expand on the movies rather well.\n\nUltimately, if you're a fan of the Back to the Future movies and/or you've enjoyed Telltales more well known titles, you'll proabably have fun with this game too.

If you grew up in the 80's, you probably watched Back to the Future with Michael J. Fox.  It was a fun time-travel romp that didn't take itself too seriously, and it worked.  Back to the Future: the Game is fun, it doesn't take itself too seriously, and it's got the same clever humour that made the movies so enjoyable.  It's a simple game - you won't find yourself going back to old save games or stumped by puzzles - but in many ways, it's like watching the Fourth movie.  Don't buy it for the gameplay, buy it because you really liked the movie.

reviewText: For all of you who like the movies or adventure games, it's now time to get Back to the Future! The puzzles are on the easy side, but the story is deffenetly the srongest link here, with all the mayhem Marty causes with his accedental paradoxes.

A 3D walk around point and Click puzzle adventure, collect items to perform tasks and prevent terrible futures... or pasts. If you're wondering what the gameplay is like, download the demo for Wallace & Gromit (Fright of the bumblebee)  also by telltale. Play time (depending on your puzzle solving) would probably last you 45 minutes to 3 hours per episode.

It's painfully short, but that's to be expected for an episodic game.  It really does feel true to the source material.  The humor is genuinely funny, though the setting takes a while to get used to.  Most of the voice actors are dead on.  The puzzles themselves are pretty simple, or they should be if you can pick up on some patterns.  Overall, I get the impression that this series will be worth the money.\n\nMy only regret is the lack of TF2 hat.  I mean can you imagine the possibilities?  A delorean themed hat would be awesome.  And you could give it the description When this baby hits 88 miles per hour

Definitely an enjoyable game for fans of the original Back to the Future film series or for fans of graphic adventure games such as the venerable Monkey Island Series.

This game has 5 episodes with each one lasting around 3 hours and ending with a cliffhanger. Puzzle difficulty was about right, without making you feel too frustrated. There is also a good ingame hint system so you'll never truly be stuck.

It has an interesting storyline, and almost feels like it could be made into a fourth film in the franchise. Music is very faithful to the series, and the voice acting is very good. The guy who voice-acted as Marty does a very good impression. The original stars Michael J Fox and Christopher Lloyd even lends their voices giving it a very authentic feel.

I personally felt that the story was too short as it ended too soon. There is also no replayability value once the game is completed.

Overall Rating: 7.5 / 10

Back to the Future: The Game is now over 5 years old. It was released in conjunction with the 25th anniversary of the first film. Now that the 30th anniversary is behind us, and 2015 came and left, can this game survive on its own merits?

As a Back to the Future" game it hits all the right notes. References to the films aren't clustered too close together and surprise you when you least expect them. It feels more like "Back to the Future" than any other game that shared that title before. The characters are familiar and their portrayal in this game feels very authentic. In many ways this game feels like a genuine piece of the film's legacy that had been lost to the ages.

As a point and click adventure game it is a bit too simple. The puzzles seemed too easy at times and there were very few times when I needed to consult the in game hint box. Every puzzle has an obvious solution and the game's objective reminders guarantees that the player doesn't get too far off the path.

Simple though it is the game is fun and I would gladly reccommend it to any fan of the series."

I've just finished episode 5 and I can say that I really enjoyed this game.
First off, lets keep in mind that it's clear that the Telltale formula wasn't fully developed here. There's no moral dilemmas because there's no choices to be made in this game. It's not a branched narrative.
The graphics aren't 2016 worthy and it crashes a lot. BUT there's an amazing cinematic feel to every episode.
It's extremely difficult, even impossible to play without using the hints that are given to you. You will be stuck in a puzzle for a long time because most puzzles make no sense.
The most important aspect is obviously the story itself. I'm not a Back to the Future fan but I really enjoyed seeing all these characters that we got to meet on the big screen.
It's a fun game that I don't regret playing.
If you like the movies, you'll like this game.

This game is a must have for fans of the movie trilogy and just fans of these types of point and click games in general. It has quite a few flaws that i will detail below, but the good triumphs over the bad if the game is on sale.

Good aspects:

Detailed and well thought out story that links all five episodes together - Each story has logical and believable writing and execution in relation to the movies. The motives of the characters is similar to that of what was in the movies and it is told well enough.

Great voice acting/dialogue/characters - the person portraying Marty sounds so similar to Mr. Fox in the movies that i kept on actually believing that it really was him doing his best vocal impression of himself at that young age. Christopher Lloyd was also a delight to listen to. As were the other lead characters for the most part.

Nostalgia - The game nails it when it comes to bringing memories back from the movies,  referencing certain aspects of the three movies and just celebrating the most memorable lines, moments and scenes in the movie trilogy without over doing it.

Bad aspects:

Presentation/animation - The character renders and overall presentation is quite bad in comparison to other games that celebrate famous movies (such as Ghostbusters: The Video Game, which came out a year earlier and which looked well detailed and thorogh in its visual appearance snd actually lets you roam around freely with very few issues) Roaming around in the Hill Valley in this game can seem like somewhat of a chore at times with the limitations on where you can walk and the camera angles nearly impossoble to manouvere. That doesn't change whether you use the keyboard controls or your mouse. The design of Hill Valley looks decent enough, but the whole presentation and animations of the chatacters could have been way better if the right time and money was invested. Still, it was still ok and not game breaking for me. Graphically, the game doesn't look as if it reaches its potential.

Choice-based gameplay being limited - The choices that they let your character make are very limiting and don't really add much to your path in the story because whichever options you pick, your character will ultimately go always go in the same path. That is because with the options they provide you during interaction with various characters, you almost always have to pick all of them to move forward in the story. For example, playing as Marty, as you're interacting with Doc Brown you need to find out a specific piece of information and are given four or more choices of questions or phrases you can ask/provide, but you have to ask pretty much all of them to get to where you need to so there isn't really a huge amount of choice involved in actuality.

Overall, it is a very good game for what it is that would be most enjoyed if you're a fan of the movie series that could have been amazing if a little more time and money were invested into this. Probably not worth it for the full price, but is great value when on sale.

However, if they released a sequel to this (whether in episodic format or otherwise), then i would definitely buy it especially if they fixed the flaws that were in this game.

10/10 would travel back in time again.

reviewText:
This Telltale-Game is a pretty sweet sequel to the movie franchise.

Story
In 1986 you play as Marty and witness how Doc's properties are being sold and suddenly the DeLorean appears which gives to the clue that the real Doc has problems in the past and you must help him.
And of course like in the movies you will stumble in some excellent adventures (...oh wrong movie :D) including changing the past and the future.
Without spoiling to much of the storyline:
you will go back to the year 1931 than back to an alternate 1986 and of course back to 1931 and a little bit of the wildwest (only a few moments at the end of the game).

The whole story will be told in 5 episodes. (You get all 5 episodes with one buy.)
Every episode will end with a twist and a short look to the next episode.


The graphics...
...are nicely done.
You don't need a high end cpu to run this game.
The characters and environment have a comic book design which looks pretty sweet and you recognize all the characters from the movies.


The gameplay...
...is really simple as you just do point and click und move with mouse or keyboard.


The soundtrack...
...is awesome but hey, its just the same themes as in the movies!!!
I'm glad they got the rights and didn't use new themes because otherwise it would be horrible.


The voice acting...
The voice actors are doing a good job.
Christopher Lloyd as Doc Brown is the only actor from the movies who does the voice acting on this game.
All the other characters are beeing dubbed by different actors.
AJ Locascio does a an amazing job portraiting Marty McFly.
Michael J. Fox has a voice cameo in the 5th episode!!


Only two cons:
- no achievemnts
- no trading cards


I totally recommend it for young and mature people who love the Back to the Future movies!!

Back to the Future is my favorite movie and this game did a great job continuing the story for me.  If you like Back to the Future or point and click adventures strongly consider this.  If you are like me and enjoy both, don't think twice, buy now!

If you enjoyed the trilogy movies, this game puts the films to shame. If you enjoyed other Telltales games  Walking Dead, Game of Thrones and Wolf Among us (I've played & finished them all), this game also puts them all to shame. This is how good the game is.

Amazing game, even if your not an adventure gamer.

Pros:
- Young Doc was terribly adorable.
- I appreciated that Christopher Lloyd reprised his role as Doc (and MFox did a cameo in Ep 5)
- The Opening/Ending mirrored the movies (which made everything feel lovely)
- The story was interesting
- Playing the game got easier to navigate

Cons:
- The story stopped being interesting after Ep 3
- It was hard to control Marty in Eps 1/2
- Ep 5 can be summarized as: 'finding/killing doc then being the inbetweener between a familly argument because no one is willing to talk to one another' (no spoilers in that sentence, don't worry)
- Ep 3 can be summarized as 'doing nothing while you run around talking to people then the story ends'
- The animation was so off at times. Sometimes simple things like a WALK CYCLE was not done correctly and Marty looked like he was walking with straight legs
- Sometimes the animation stops or the dialogue stops while the animation catches up
- The ending feels like an absolute cop out

I know this is one of TellTales older games but I was expecting development from ep1 to ep5 (such as game mechanics getting better). But it feels unpolished. Simple things, such as making sure that a walking cycle looks believable shouldn't be neglected in any game, even if it's coming from an indie developer.

I really love Back to the Future but this didn't feel like what the franchise deserved. It's more of a causal game than an 'adventure game' since I basically did nothing but walk Marty from place to place.

tl;dr: Doc gets a new girlfriend and then the story gets dull. The end.

Basically indirect sequals to the movies, great design and an overall enjoyable nostalgic adventure. You should get about 4-6 hours per episode if you don't try to speedrush through it for the story. Kinda wish it were a bit more difficult tbh\n\n8.5/10

3-the gameplay is fairly linear if you want to finish quickly, but offers a lot of exploration if you want to go around.
4-character design is unique and spectacular, they are rememberable and believable.
5-it's a classic, i didn't watch the original movie, which is a historical landmark in movies.
3-the story is actually very very well written, it will captivate you, which is why;

I never want a BttF remake, or a sequel. This was enough of a 'new' BttF fix to keep me content with the fact we'll never see Marty outwit that butthead Biff ever again.

All gushing aside, this game is pretty great. The voice acting is fantastic (considering Doc Brown is actually Christopher Lloyd's voice), they had a great voice actor to play Marty and other notable characters. It's a typical point and click that Telltale does well, and right from the getgo it feels like you never left Hill Valley.

Though this game is great to me, I'm easy to please when it comes to BttF stuff so it might not be for everybody. The storyline does get pretty damn cheesy from time to time, but it's still fun to see what's going to happen next. There's even a few surprises along the way that make the journey worthwhile.

If you love BttF: buy this. If you're not a die-hard fan, or unsure if you'll really enjoy this, buy this while it's still on sale.

Back to the Future: The Game is mostly a point-and-click puzzle-solving game spread over 5 episodes.

I completed it in about 11 hours.  The regular price seems rather high to me, but I got it on the Steam Summer Sale for something like $5 which was totally worth it.

Gameplay is not the greatest.  Most puzzles are relatively easy, but there were a couple that I had to go online for a walkthrough to get past.

Story is fantastic and true to the movies.

Voice-acting includes some of the actors from the movies.

Graphics are in a computer-animated style (think slightly lower-quality Pixar).

Overall, as a game by itself there are better point and click puzzle solvers out there.  But looking at it as the fourth movie in the series, it is epic.  If you like the movies I highly recommend this.  It gives you that one more adventure with the characters we came to love 30 years ago.

There are two ways to look at this game. One way is if your a fan of Telltale games. The other is if you are a back to the future fan. In this case, I am the later half.

Telltale perspective: I have played their more well know games such as TWD (both seasons) and The Wolf Among us. Both of which felt a little more creative. The Game also took me about 10 hours which seemed a little short for their games. The one thing that stuck out the most was that if you played their other games, get ready for a change, granted this is one of the first game like TWD or any such, so do cut it some slack.

Back to the Future Perspective: Let me start off by saying I LOVE these movies (yes, even part 3). Had they decided to make a part 4, this would have worked in my opinion. They refrence the movies through out the episodes and try to stay true to everyones personalities in them. I was also surprised to see Christopher Lloyd play Doc Brown throught the whole game and see Micheal J. Fox play William Mcfly (Marty's Great grandpa). They even got Tom Wilson to voice Biff on home consoles.

How ever there were a fair share of things that couldve been fixed/ would be nice but not need to fix. (No spoilers) The end of episode 5 completly falls apart and then leaves it on a cliff hanger most notably.

There is rumor that the sequal is being made, but is bottem on the priority list, but hopefully Telltale will publish it soon.

Overall, I would say definitly try it your a BttF fan, even if you dont like it, you'll probably like some of the refrences to the movies. It certainly beats BttF on NES. Its a maybe for you Telltale fans, like I said, this was the first of their style of games. But regarless of what you think,

If you're a BTTF fan, you should absolutely play this. The only it may turn most people off is it's a point and click with some very arbitrary puzzles.

It's ironic that a game about time travel arrived one year too early before TellTale started to add depth of choice and consequence to their games, as this is just a linear story. You can't blame the game for that, it's just unfortunate that the title that would've benefited most from the modern TellTale treatment just barely missed it.\n\nIt definitely has its moments, clever nods to BttF did not go unnoticed, and the voice acting is great. Marty's actor sounds a bit affected in Episode 1, but after that he really nails it. At one point, I was thinking, Man
date: Doc's voice actor is spot on too
recommended: only to find out that, yeah, it's Christopher Lloyd. That works. I wasn't enraptured by the main direction of the story -- it worked as a what-if
hoursPlayed:
maybe not BttF IV caliber -- but I really liked a few places they took it.

Ultimately, while there is good, this game didn't add up for me. A lot of the gameplay is tedious and mundane, the mechanics can be wonky, and the narrative is hit-and-miss... and-miss. Hit-and-miss-and-miss is appropriate for much of the game, as it can feel like a dated, drab experience. In a lot of ways, it's a second-rate game.

It's BttF, so give it a spin. I wouldn't say it's worth the time, personally, but there are some good bits here and you'll probably surmise whether you like the game or not in the first two hours. If you don't, just change history and return it.

Date: 2/13/16
Review Number: 16 (Bank Review #2)
Game: Back to the Future Episode 1
From (Creator Publisher): Telltale Games
Played On: Steambox (Steam Controller)
Steam Price as of Review:
Total Time played: 2+ Hours (Wife observing for all of it)
Review:

For the second review of the vacation, I decided to do something else a bit different.   Now a bit of personal info here, I am married (have been for a decade) and my wife, though not exactly crazy about video games, does enjoy a round or two of some games in my collection.  After she was finished with a round, and since there was nothing on TV, I decided to take over for a round.  Looking through a collection for something we both would enjoy, my choice was quickly overridden when my wife noticed that I had a Back to the Future adventure game.  So we took the time to fire up Telltale Game’s Back to the Future episode 1, a point and click adventure game with so many of the original cast and staff involved that it might as well be considered a sequel of sorts, though granted some thirty years afterwards.

And sequel this very well could be; the writing is superb, the voices so on par, with many of the original characters playing themselves (sans the main character, though Michael J Fox does do some cameo appearances as the non-1985-prime McFly family) this is in many ways a continuation of the Back to the Future series that works well in-canon.  The graphics are pretty, and the animations are fantastic.  The controls are fantastic, and work surprisingly well with the Steam Gamepad.  The only part of the interface that I thought was a little odd was the inventory screen, but even with that, I found that the game parts of the game were so unobtrusive that I could often just ‘go through the motions’ of playing the game and feel like I was just watching a movie.  Indeed, if someone is looking for a more robust ‘adventure’ game, they may find this game somewhat lacking for that reason. Even with a  lot of interactable objects in each area, the game still feels like you only head in one direction, moving along a very specific course with interactable objects proving just a bit of flair.  In the end though, this game is a beautiful continuation of a fantastic movie series, and I fully intend to play this all the way through to it's conclusion. Anyone who loves the movies, or loves point and click adventure games, will eat this up.  Buy buy buy!

Game’s Fate: Kept on the Steambox, will occasionally play it
Buy/No Buy: If you like point and click adventure games, this one isn’t necessarily the most difficult or engaging, but it's enjoyable enough, and fans of the movies will love them.  Buy.

Back to the Future: The Game does a stunning job of recapturing the feel and flavor of the film trilogy that inspired it. Despite lacking some of the functionality Telltale's become known for in later games, especially regards to consequence, BttF is a solid adventure experience through and through with only a few bits I found frustrating.

Set (initially) in Prohibition-era Hill Valley, the bulk of Back to the Future: The Game is an exploration of Doc Brown's past, and how he became the eccentric genius scientist we know him as in the movies. After tracking down Doc following a journey gone a bit awry, Marty McFly's stuck juggling multiple eras of Doc and eventually having to deal with a much different Doc than he's used to. The consequences of minor changes are even more evident this time around than they were in the films, though the quests to fix those changes show a wide variety of Hill Valleys that were and could have been.

First things first, I need to commend all the performers they got to fill the various roles. Marty McFly's voice actor is a dead ringer for 80's-era Michael J. Fox, and the rest of the familiar cast is well-represented. New characters abound without overwhelming familiar faces, and are all established firmly enough that you care about them, be it out of love or of loathing. It's nice that the game manages to give Marty's history some time in the spotlight as well, despite all the focus on Doc.

Progress in the game is based primarily on conversation, working your way through options to figure out what's going on, what to do next, and how to get people to do what you need. There are several points where this can get tedious and/or unclear as to how to proceed, but those bits are few and far between, especially as you get into the later episodes. There's a bit of item collection and use, but it takes a back seat to the dialogue trees, which makes for a great showcase of Telltale's writing skill. Action sequences pop up from time to time as well, which add to the cinematic feel of the game but are also the weakest, gameplay-wise. Several times, I found myself going in circles trying to figure out how to finish an action sequence, only to find I was missing a single, relatively tiny (visually and figuratively) piece of the puzzle. I guess my best advice for these bits is to look up. Always look up.

Other than that, Back to the Future: The Game is absolutely worth your time. A fitting tribute to the films, these five episodes could easily be considered canon if they aren't already.

A classic adventure game. Solve puzzles to progress the story. It's not like the recent TellTale games in which your decisions effect the story. It's more of a 'Full Throttle' or 'Kings Quest' style of adventure game.

Although Back to the Future: The Game lacks the pinache of The Walking Dead, Wolf Among Us, etc. and the games that have come after, the game was fun in its own right. It's a very linear adventure game where you have to solve the puzzle in a very specific way to move the story forward. There's no story branching and while the game doesn't really have the same awe-factor as the movies, it still holds a charm of its own. The voice actor for Marty is pretty spot on for a Michael J. Fox and Christopher Lloyd reprises his role as Doc Brown. The various versions of the characters you meet in the 1920s and the alternate realities of 1986 are interesting and unique. It's a nice trip back down nostalgia lane to have the crew of Back to the Future take you on one last ride.

I only recommend this game on sale to fans of the BTTF movies. It is a a bare bones point & click linear adventure game with many mildly infuriating components, but is a faithful 5 episode sequel to the BTTF movies.  You play as Marty McFly in 1985 which starts with an homage to the first movie, but takes place after the 3 movies.

Cons::
One track linear story: Your actions don't affect what happens in the story other than progressing it linearly and definitely do not carry over between episodes.  Choose Your Own Adventure books offer more choice.

Dialog selection not consistent with voice acting: On a regular basis I select a dialog choice, and Marty says something that differs in tone and/or content from what I selected, as if voice script was rewritten after the dialog UI was setup.

Movement limited between areas: In 1st episode movement is limited from the front of the courthouse to either side of the courthouse.

Graphics same as lowest common ported denominator: Aside from antialiasing, I may as well have run the game on a Nintendo Wii.  Low poly counts on characters is a bad choice for such a character & dialog driven game.

Episodes have separate settings and launchers: Ever change any of the game settings? Be prepared to change them for each new episode that you launch.  There is no central UI for accessing each of the episodes.


Pros::
Story and atmosphere: This is a story that fits the franchise well and has a number of nuanced details that fans will appreciate.

Voice acting: Telltale found an impressive Fox soundalike actor and Christopher Lloyd's return is great, along with decent supporting voice acting.

Hint system: Great for casual players.

There are two ways to look at this game. One way is if your a fan of Telltale games. The other is if you are a back to the future fan. In this case, I am the later half.

Telltale perspective: I have played their more well know games such as TWD (both seasons) and The Wolf Among us. Both of which felt a little more creative. The Game also took me about 10 hours which seemed a little short for their games. The one thing that stuck out the most was that if you played their other games, get ready for a change, granted this is one of the first game like TWD or any such, so do cut it some slack.

Back to the Future Perspective: Let me start off by saying I LOVE these movies (yes, even part 3). Had they decided to make a part 4, this would have worked in my opinion. They refrence the movies through out the episodes and try to stay true to everyones personalities in them. I was also surprised to see Christopher Lloyd play Doc Brown throught the whole game and see Micheal J. Fox play William Mcfly (Marty's Great grandpa). They even got Tom Wilson to voice Biff on home consoles.

How ever there were a fair share of things that couldve been fixed/ would be nice but not need to fix. (No spoilers) The end of episode 5 completly falls apart and then leaves it on a cliff hanger most notably.

There is rumor that the sequal is being made, but is bottem on the priority list, but hopefully Telltale will publish it soon.

Overall, I would say definitly try it your a BttF fan, even if you dont like it, you'll probably like some of the refrences to the movies. It certainly beats BttF on NES. Its a maybe for you Telltale fans, like I said, this was the first of their style of games. But regarless of what you think,
