Date: 2/13/16
Review Number: 16 (Bank Review #2)
Game: Back to the Future Episode 1
From (Creator Publisher): Telltale Games
Played On: Steambox (Steam Controller)
Steam Price as of Review:
Total Time played: 2+ Hours (Wife observing for all of it)
Review:

For the second review of the vacation, I decided to do something else a bit different.   Now a bit of personal info here, I am married (have been for a decade) and my wife, though not exactly crazy about video games, does enjoy a round or two of some games in my collection.  After she was finished with a round, and since there was nothing on TV, I decided to take over for a round.  Looking through a collection for something we both would enjoy, my choice was quickly overridden when my wife noticed that I had a Back to the Future adventure game.  So we took the time to fire up Telltale Game’s Back to the Future episode 1, a point and click adventure game with so many of the original cast and staff involved that it might as well be considered a sequel of sorts, though granted some thirty years afterwards.

And sequel this very well could be; the writing is superb, the voices so on par, with many of the original characters playing themselves (sans the main character, though Michael J Fox does do some cameo appearances as the non-1985-prime McFly family) this is in many ways a continuation of the Back to the Future series that works well in-canon.  The graphics are pretty, and the animations are fantastic.  The controls are fantastic, and work surprisingly well with the Steam Gamepad.  The only part of the interface that I thought was a little odd was the inventory screen, but even with that, I found that the game parts of the game were so unobtrusive that I could often just ‘go through the motions’ of playing the game and feel like I was just watching a movie.  Indeed, if someone is looking for a more robust ‘adventure’ game, they may find this game somewhat lacking for that reason. Even with a  lot of interactable objects in each area, the game still feels like you only head in one direction, moving along a very specific course with interactable objects proving just a bit of flair.  In the end though, this game is a beautiful continuation of a fantastic movie series, and I fully intend to play this all the way through to it's conclusion. Anyone who loves the movies, or loves point and click adventure games, will eat this up.  Buy buy buy!

Game’s Fate: Kept on the Steambox, will occasionally play it
Buy/No Buy: If you like point and click adventure games, this one isn’t necessarily the most difficult or engaging, but it's enjoyable enough, and fans of the movies will love them.  Buy.

reviewText:
This game came out in 2011. Can't believe it's been that long already! It would be silly of me to make assumptions, but what the hey ... it's fun :) I'm willing to bet that Back to the Future: The Game is what set the precedence for the success of The Walking Dead and then later The Wolf Among Us. It's as clear as seeing the connection between Call of Juarez: The Cartel being a precedence for Dead Island.

I haven't played the CSI series from TellTale Games, but I remember a friend speaking highly of it to me one day whilst we were travelling to Uni. My gut feeling tells me that would have contained the ground work of the TellTale Tool (game engine), enhanced over the years.

Back to the Future: The Game is more akin to a true point and click adventure. There are triggers embedded within dialogue that progress the story as opposed to The Walking Dead and The Wolf Among Us, in which selecting dialogue has no effect other than customising the story to the player's liking. I mean, there were some portions like that, but it was quite impassive. And your choices in one episode will not be carried to any other episodes.

The gameplay is quite challenging in figuring out what to do next. Sometimes there are tiny interactive hotspots on the screen that you never think about clicking on (like a small switch), other times you have to figure out which item in your inventory that you must use on an interactive hotspot.

Luckily there is a pretty cool system that gives you hints bit by bit and only when you want them. I found myself using an average of 3 hints for each episode (mainly out of impatience). If this were the early 90's, this would be the type of game that you'd get stuck on for a day and try to figure it out by asking friends at school, lol.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=glUXst_yYKw
The story in Back to the Future: The Game was actually kind of painful. Each episode was about fixing Marty's broken 1986 reality after accidently altering an event amongst characters back in 1931. The annoying feeling is the same thing you feel when watching Back to the Future 2 and Biff Tannen owns everything. But there are also hilarious moments in the game. It's very up and down. Some parts in some episodes you'd rate 90/100 and other parts you'd give as low as 40/100. If I had to give an aggregate score, I'd probably rate the entire game 68/100.

For the die hard fans, there are lots of cameos and parodies made via dialogue and recognisable 3d model objects. This may sound lame ... but this game is very Back to the Futureish and wouldn't be so if there wern't all these cameo's like a guy yelling, Hey! He just took that guy's wallet! I think he took his wallet."

In conclusion (and please don't hate me peeps)
date: but this game really ain't worth $5USD on special. I remember around the same year this game called L.A Noir was released. In my opinion that game whilst being open-world ... was very much an advance point and click adventure as well. Shortly after
recommended: L.A Noir hit about $3.75USD. But the point is
hoursPlayed: it was pretty damn advance compared to Back to the Future: The Game
voteText: engine-wise ... which did seem unfinished somewhat ... I mean invisible walls ... really? Even each episode (1-5) was released as a separate game download causing you each time to configure things like screen resolution."

Video Review (for those who don't like reading): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XVK0C6F3NY8

Back to the Future: The Game is a puzzle-adventure game taking inspiration from point-and-click titles. You click on various items to interact with them or investigate them, and use the items and your surroundings to solve puzzles that advance the story. Does it work? Well, yes and no. When it comes to video games, there’s an age-old question: Gameplay or Story: which is more important? Well, if you’ve ever been on the fence about this question, then Back to the Future: The Game will solve it for you in the first half an hour.

First, the story is astounding. It manages to fully capture all the magic and feel of the original movies while still being its own thing. After playing through the whole game, I, and I’d say most other people who played it, felt the story alone made it worthy to bear the title of Back to the Future Part IV. Considering that it was a collaboration from the people at Telltale Games, the people behind Tales from the Borderlands, and the guys who made the original three movies, and the story writer for this game happens to be the very same person who wrote the original three movies, I’m not all that surprised, though I am impressed that they managed to capture the same magic of the original movies more than twenty-five years after they released. The voice work is fantastic all-around, unsurprising since they got some of the original actors to play their parts, and every new character feels like they always belonged in the Back to the Future universe. For the most part, the dialog is well-written, the graphics are surprisingly fitting and work well, and the music is…directly stolen from the movies. Of course, the soundtrack of the movies is fantastic, so that’s not necessarily a bad thing. In addition, the puzzles are clever without being completely unfair. My favorite part of the game was during the last episode, where you have to jog somebody’s memory through giving their brain certain stimulations to represent what happened in the past. A mop head on a cactus makes a grandpa, a sign on an outhouse makes a saloon, and so on. I only ever had to look up the solution to one puzzle in the very first episode, and that ended up only being because my controller didn’t recognize a required object as an item.

And that’s where we get into what’s wrong with the game. After all, when you get a bunch of movie producers to make a video game, you can expect the story and dialog to be good, but the game itself? Not so much. Where should I start? Well, the camera is among the worst I‘ve ever seen, being annoyingly hard to control, and since most of the time you never need to manipulate it, you end up forgetting you can entirely, which makes parts of the game later on when you do need to manipulate it very confusing. It also picks these strange moments to suddenly switch perspectives, which throw you off whenever you’re trying to go somewhere across town. There are invisible walls everywhere, giving you a sort of fake-3D experience, but then often you can move around freely, and you just can’t tell the difference. Despite Hill Valley feeling so big, I feel just so constricted because of this. Plus, Marty is so slow! Even when he’s running, which, if you’re smart, he’ll always be, it still feels like it takes forever to get anywhere. All three of these aspects combined makes traversing the world around you a chore. That’s not mention the terrible controls. Here’s the thing: you’ll spend half of your time clicking, and the other half walking. Initially, it seems that a controller is the best option for both of these, as one of the control sticks can be used to skip from one clickable item onscreen to another with ease, and the other can be used to walk freely, whereas you have to drag the mouse a couple of inches away from Marty in whatever direction you want to go if you want to use the mouse. However, as I mentioned earlier, sometimes your controller will skip right over items, because it doesn’t recognize them, and very often, those items are required to solve a puzzle in the game. So you end up constantly switching between two means of controlling, using the controller to move and the mouse to click, and, trust me, it gets REALLY annoying. Also, if you hold down either the mouse or the button for more than a half a second during dialog, it sometimes acts like you clicked twice, and skips important pieces of dialog. Also, just a tip: in the first episode, a reporter will ask Marty for his name. Just tell her it’s Harry Callahan, because no matter what, everyone is going to refer to him as that.

Is playing the game a chore? Not necessarily. The music and characters keep the atmosphere up, the puzzles are fairly good, and the story makes you want to keep going. It’s more of a whether or not the story is worth drudging through the terrible camera and controls. I’ll tell you this; if Chuggaconroy ever made a let’s play of this game, I’d recommend watching it well over playing the game yourself. However, when you look at the other Steam reviews for the game, you’ll see that the vast majority are positive, and most of the negative ones simply say that the game is “meh,” and the story and gameplay cancel each other out. Many of the positive reviews say that the story is what makes the game worth playing. And here’s the thing: I think they’re right. The game is going to be really annoying to play through due to the controls, but the feeling you’ll get when you solve a puzzle is never to be underestimated, and every resulting cutscene is a reward in and of itself. I certainly wouldn’t recommend watching a walkthrough over playing it, but if you have a character of interesting personality doing a let’s play, you might want to stick to that. Still, the story, music, dialog, characters, and perfect capturing of the feel of the movies makes this game more than worth the while. On the gameinformer scale of 1-10, with 7 being average, 10 being perfection, and 1 being the Ouya controller, I’d give this game a 4 for gameplay and 9 for story, which rounds off to 6.5, and I‘ll bring it up to a 7 just so I can recommend it officially.

The thing is Telltale Games made a great game in this genre called The Wolf Among Us, and it's hard not to compare these types of games to that, and this doesn't stack up.\nWherein TWAU was a well paced story with decent action bits and amusing characters, this is awkwardly paced, has too many boring cut scenes/dialogue, with annoying game mechanics and none of the character of the films, in any sense. I found myself using the hint function within the game, not because this has difficult puzzles but simply to move the experience along as quickly as possible. That's not a good sign\nI was a huge fan of these films back in the day, and hoped this captured some of that experience in a fun interactive way, but sadly no. Go play The Wolf Among Us instead.
